Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing Diverse Phage Roles in a Defensive Symbiosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Insects and other animals are frequently infected with maternally inherited symbiotic bacteria, which can benefit their animal hosts by providing nutrition or host protection. Many beneficial symbionts are themselves infected with viruses called bacteriophages, which have the capacity to impact host biology in critical ways, yet their roles in animal-bacterial symbioses are poorly understood. In the pea aphid, Acyrthosiphon pisum, the bacterial symbiont Hamiltonella defensa confers protection from attack by parasitic wasps, but only when bacteriophages called APSEs are also present. Aside from this role in protection, little is known about the influence of APSEs on H. defensa and aphid biology, including specifically how APSEs contribute to the demise of parasites and the potential role in the regulation of symbiont abundance. This project will use a combination of approaches, including genomics and molecular biology, to characterize the roles of APSEs in the regulation and maintenance of the protective symbiosis and to identify specific factors responsible for wasp mortality.

Deciphering phage-symbiont interactions is important to the study of animal-microbial interactions generally and to understanding the biology of many economically important insects like aphids. The proposed work will yield information of practical importance for the management of pest insect populations and on the role of phages in the establishment and maintenance of bacterial-arthropod associations, which are widespread in the natural world. The interdisciplinary nature of this research is also well suited as a platform to train young scientists at the interface of symbiosis, cell biology, parasitology, and molecular processes. This project will train high school students, undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insects are the most diverse and abundant animals on the planet and provide numerous benefits to humans including pollination, nutrient cycling and biological control. Some insects also negatively impact humans as agricultural pests or vectors of disease-causing pathogens. Most insect species, whether beneficial or pestiferous, are infected with microbial partners, including bacteria and viruses, that aid them in the acquisition of resources or defense.

Aphids are small insects that feed on plant sap (phloem) and often harm plants by transmitting pathogens. They are also biologically interesting because they have bacterial partners called symbionts that assist them in using phloem for food and in their defense against natural enemies. In our project, we studied the pea aphid, Acyrthosiphon pisum, which is infected with a bacterial symbiont called Hamiltonella defensa that protects aphids from attack by internally-developing parasitic wasps. An intriguing complexity is that the bacterial symbiont must itself be infected by viruses (bacteriophages) called APSEs for aphid defense. Given that the prevalence and function of phages in insect symbiosis is little known the main goal of our project was to examine roles of APSE in the aphid protective symbiosis. 

Aphids are ideal for studying the effects of infection with bacterial symbionts because they can be reared clonally to eliminate unwanted genetic variation and their symbionts can be manipulated to engineer aphids with desired infections. These approaches have yielded many important findings, including that aphids primarily rely on infection with H. defensa and APSE for protection against the parasite Aphidius ervi. However, a major limitation of this system (and others with host-restricted bacteria) is the difficulty in studying mechanisms that underlie function using the insect model.  

Hence, a major focus of this project was to develop the ability to culture and study H. defensa, APSE and the parasites outside of aphids. Successfully culturing H. defensa in vitro, to levels similar to those found in aphids, resulted in parasite mortality.  Further, removing the symbionts and assaying only their products also harmed wasps. These assays coupled with microscopy revealed that H. defensa/APSE releases soluble factors that enter wasp eggs and disable development. These tools are being used in ongoing studies to identify the specific factor(s) that cause mortality. In vitro studies further showed that some APSE strains produce infectious particles that infect phage-free H. defensa strains with subsequent virus acquisition restoring the killing ability of the bacterial symbiont.

Also discovered was that loss of APSE led to large increases in the within aphid abundance of H. defensa and that observed increases in titers were associated with substantial harm to aphid fitness. Thus, phage loss leads to the breakdown of the defensive symbiosis via the elimination of defensive services and additional costs of harboring phage-less symbionts. However, lateral transfer experiments show that APSEs can also move back into phage-free H. defensa infected aphids. Phage acquisition not only restores protection against parasites, but also reduces symbiont abundance. These studies are important in showing how phages play roles in the regulation and maintenance of bacterial symbionts in natural populations.  

Different strains of H. defensa and their associated APSE symbionts correlate with varying levels of aphid defense against parasites. Another goal of this project was to explore variation in H. defensa/APSE strains from pea aphids and other aphid species. Several new strains were identified and experiments showed these provided high levels of protection against parasitoids. The ability to culture symbionts was then used to produce high quality template for genomic and transcriptomic studies. This template was free of contamination of nucleic acids from aphids or other bacteria, which is normally a challenge for insects with host-restricted bacterial. This material was then used to sequence the complete genomes of numerous strains of H.  defensa allowing identification of key factors underlying strain variation in this defensive symbiont. We also used culture-facilitated template generation for transcriptomic studies to complement enemy-challenged transcriptomic studies conducted with aphid material.

In summary, the project has significantly advanced a leading model of defensive symbiosis and developed tools useful to the broader host-microbe community studying topics ranging from molecular mechanisms to community ecology. This project furthers our understanding and appreciation of how hidden microbial players contribute to outcomes observed at the scale of animal-animal interactions. This project also contributed substantially to the training and professional development of three graduate researchers, two post-doctoral associates as well as high-school and undergraduate researchers. The work has been disseminated at domestic and international venues and resulted in the publication of research articles and book chapters with addition publications in preparation.
